meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: Barbara as yeah as co-moderator also with Barbara here. I want to just share experiences over two decades in measuring the metabolon, metabolites in a human body, right? What what what we refer to as the metabolome is the collection of small molecules that are present. If you go and you measure in your blood in an annual test checkup, you measure glucose, cholesterol, and what we have done as a metabolomics community over the past two decades is to scale up the knowledge about the measure of these chemicals in the blood, in tissue, in the brain, in in any organ that you can imagine and say, have we really missed on some of our biochemistry? Have we missed information available in these small molecules that do convey significant information about our health and therefore as a community over two decades of metabolomics, lipidomics researchers, we have expanded the horizon so that we can measure 2,000, 3,000 chemicals in the blood that we can identify, that we can name.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: The interesting thing is that a large part of the molecules that we see in the blood are derived we think a good part of them are derived by bacteria, by bacteria that can metabolize things we eat, right? In particular we we we saw a lot of work on the fibers, right? The fibers that we eat and the whole area of research, a body of research over a decade showing that the short chain you know fatty acids are maybe one plus and it's only a tip of the iceberg in terms of a whole area of metabolites that are produced by this gut bacteria.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: The gut bacteria is a partner with us, is a partner with the humans together we shape our metabolism. You look at pathways such as cholesterol or pathways such as indoles, tryptophan leading to indole production and you say my goodness, half of the pathway is catalyzed by human genes, the other half of the pathway is catalyzed by bacterial enzymes. Yes? You know, I give you an example, tryptophan, tryptophan can be metabolized to serotonin, to canurine, to right 5HIA or it can go to the gut and get metabolized by bacteria in the gut to produce indoles. Some of these indoles, right? Depending on what bacteria you have in your gut, you can produce indoxyl sulfate. We heard from the beautiful presentation of Rosie, some of the sulfated compounds, their their effect in autism, we see them now in depression, we see them in anxiety, we see them linked to cognition. So the bacteria is completing our metabolism.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: Things we produce through human genes can be further metabolized by bacteria to produce a whole area of chemicals, who knows what they do, clearly they have biological functions and clearly a lot of them end up in the brain. We were quite amazed and surprised to see that things like the indoxyl sulfate, the metabolism of cholesterol ending in the secondary bile acids, these are all produced by bacteria, they are all in the brain in 500 brains we looked at.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: We asked the question, does you know, is there bacteria in the brain? At least in our hands with Rob Knight, our partner in a large initiative, we discovered there is no bacteria in the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rima kaddurah daouk
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yet all of these chemicals that are produced by bacteria are in the brain. So it's a summary.
